channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Justice Dept. Appeals Part of Special Master Review in Trump Case
item.description: The government, while calling a lower court’s decision “unprecedented,” did not seek to stop the installation of an outside arbiter to review other materials taken from Mar-a-Lago.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The filing sets up a clash between the Justice Department, pictured above, and former President Donald J. Trump at the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta.

item.title: Lawyer Told Archives Last Year That Trump Had No Classified Material
item.description: A lawyer representing the former president told the National Archives that boxes taken from the White House contained material like newspaper clippings.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:description: Patrick Philbin, a former top White House lawyer, is said to have indicated last year that Mr. Trump had taken only nonclassified material in boxes from the White House.

item.title: The Job of the Special Master in the Trump Documents Inquiry, Explained
item.description: A judge’s order detailed the tasks of the independent arbiter appointed to filter material the F.B.I. seized from the former president’s residence.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Rachel Mummey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The special master will examine more than 11,000 documents the F.B.I. took from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida compound during a court-authorized search on Aug. 8.

item.title: Trump’s Lawyers Could Face Legal Troubles of Their Own
item.description: Several of the former president’s lawyers are under scrutiny by federal investigators amid squabbling over competence.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Eric Herschmann, a former White House lawyer for President Donald J. Trump, was a prominent witness in the House Jan. 6 hearings.

item.title: Putin Threatens to Escalate War as India Distances Itself From Russia
item.description: After India’s prime minister said that now is not the time for war, an increasingly isolated Mr. Putin threatened “more serious” actions in Ukraine while insisting he was ready for talks.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Mujib Mashal and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, who met President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday, told the Russian president that “today’s era is not of war.”

item.title: Ukraine’s Donbas, Where Putin Sowed the Seeds of War
item.description: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road outside Chasiv Yar with mountains of slag visible on the horizon.

item.title: Biden Meets With Relatives of Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan
item.description: The White House has been under pressure to release the
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, a W.N.B.A. star, in a court building outside of Moscow in August. She has been held in Russia since mid-February.

item.title: Migrants Flown to Martha’s Vineyard Say They Were Misled
item.description: The flights, arranged by Florida’s Republican governor, underscored how easily the fate of immigrants can be swept up in politics.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times

item.title: How Scores of Migrants Were Sent to Martha’s Vineyard and D.C.
item.description: The migrant drop-offs orchestrated by two Republican governors raised questions about how the law treats immigrants. Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and daughter, who were recently flown to Martha's Vineyard, Mass., aboard a ferry to the mainland on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Immigration Debate Rings Hollow in Venezuela as Migrants Flee
item.description: More than a fifth of Venezuela’s population has fled the country, and critics said the move by Republican governors to ship migrants to other states would not dissuade others from leaving.
item.dc:creator: Sheyla Urdaneta, Julie Turkewitz and Isayen Herrera
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants boarding buses at a ferry terminal on Martha’s Vineyard on Friday. The migrant were flown there by Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican from Florida.

item.title: Stocks Slide in One of Wall Street’s Worst Weeks This Year
item.description: Pessimism is deepening as bellwether companies like FedEx and General Electric warn of worsening economic and business conditions.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Yeshiva University Halts All Student Clubs to Block L.G.B.T.Q. Group
item.description: Earlier in the week, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed a ruling to stand for now that required the university to recognize the group.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:description: Yeshiva University had been ordered by a judge to recognize an L.G.B.T.Q. student group under New York City’s anti-discrimination law.

item.title: The California County Where MAGA Took Control
item.description: In a state run by Democrats, Shasta County is a rare instance where far-right activists dominate board meetings and exert power.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Woody Clendenen, a barber and activist in Shasta County, talking politics with his clients at his shop in Cottonwood, Calif.

item.title: King Charles Faces Challenges but Is Off to a Stirring Start
item.description: King Charles III has had an enthusiastic public reception so far, but for this man of strong opinions, replacing the beloved queen will be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III and his siblings standing vigil beside the coffin of their mother, Queen Elizabeth II, as it lies in state on the catafalque in Westminster Hall on Friday.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Mourning the Queen and the Past
item.description: A memorial for Elizabeth has given residents of the former British colony a rare platform for public, if quiet, political dissent.
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang and John Yoon
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Waiting to pay tribute to Queen Elizabeth II outside the British Consulate General in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Haiti’s Fuel Price Hike Escalates Its Worst Protests in Years
item.description: Discontent over economic misery spilled into the largest national protests in years, prompting international calls for action.
item.dc:creator: Milo Milfort, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andre Paultre
item.media:description: Protesters erected burning barricades in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Thursday, as the country was racked by widespread protests.

item.title: Siddhartha Mukherjee Weaves History and Biology to Tell the Story of Us
item.description: His forthcoming book, “The Song of the Cell,” part of what he says will be a quartet, is “fundamentally about understanding the units that organize our life.”
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: The Song of the Cell: An Exploration of Medicine and the New Human (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Sommerfeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I love making things,” Mukherjee said, whether “a book, a therapy, a medicine, a whatever it might be. Especially when they didn’t exist before. I love the idea of bringing something into the world.”

item.title: New York Has an Obligation to Secure the Education of Hasidic Children
item.description: Politicians have known for years about the crisis facing New York’s Hasidic schools but failed to act in any meaningful way.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: DeSantis’s Martha’s Vineyard Migrants Stunt Shows the Asylum System Is Broken
item.description: America’s immigration system has long been overburdened and outdated.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

item.title: Trying to Prove You’re Not a Racist
item.description: Saying you agree with my opinions on race may only dig your hole deeper.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter

item.title: Wonking Out: What Ukraine Needs From Us
item.description: Lawyers, guns and money. OK, skip the lawyers.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: The Story Behind the Averted Rail Strike Is About Employers and Exploitation
item.description: The single best thing President Biden and the Democratic Party could do for workers is to give them the tools and support to build power for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:description: State troopers were sent to maintain order in Illinois in 1922, when seven of the 16 railroad unions went on strike around the country.

item.title: Humans Have a Long History of Making ‘Very Bad Decisions’ to Save Animals
item.description: As scientists push the frontiers of conservation technology, some of their initiatives raise ethical questions.
item.dc:creator: Tim McDonnell

item.title: Nuclear Power Still Doesn’t Make Much Sense
item.description: There’s a lot of new enthusiasm around nuclear power. It isn’t warranted.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo
item.media:credit: Michael Holahan/The Augusta Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Plant Vogtle nuclear energy facility in Waynesboro, Ga.

item.title: Extreme Religious Liberty Is Undermining Public Health
item.description: Recent rulings are empowering the moral judgments of a small but politically powerful group.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay F. Wiley

item.title: The climate philanthropists
item.description: The founder of the Patagonia clothing company is handing the business to a nonprofit group. We look at climate giving and why this move is different.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Natalie Behring for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yvon Chouinard founded Patagonia in 1973.

item.title: The Future of San Francisco’s Fog and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
item.media:credit: Nina Riggio for The New York Times

item.title: How to Prepare for Flu Season
item.description: We may be more susceptible to the virus than we have been in recent years, but doctors have tips to stay healthy.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Woman’s Death in Iran After Arrest by the Morality Police Triggers Outrage
item.description: Masha Amini was detained for allegedly violating dress rules. Her suspicious death, publicized by social media, has led to protests and condemnations by prominent Iranians.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An undated picture of Mahsa Amini, provided to Iran Wire by her family.

item.title: Appeals Court Upholds Texas Social Media Law on Censorship
item.description: The law, which had been blocked by a lower court, makes it possible to sue large social media platforms for taking down political viewpoints.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe

item.title: Privilege Is in Crisis. Look at Our Elite Private Schools.
item.description: The past few years have witnessed a lot of upheaval in the name of political reckoning. Is the pendulum swinging back to tradition?
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:description: The current dilemma among high school leaders at Grace Church School is how freely students should dress.

item.title: After 75 Years, Cheetahs Return to India in a Grand Experiment
item.description: Scientists aim to determine whether a predator population can be restored in a place where it was hunted into extinction.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: A cheetah and her two grown cubs in Namibia at a Cheetah Conservation Fund enclosure. The organization is a main partner in the relocation of eight cheetahs to India this weekend.

item.title: Do Food Sensitivity Tests Work?
item.description: Food sensitivity tests are becoming increasingly popular. Here’s what the experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Are Smoothies Good For You? It Depends.
item.description: “Just because there’s a leafy green in it doesn’t make it low-calorie.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Can Protein Powders Help Aging Muscles?
item.description: Older adults typically need more protein than younger people. Here’s how to ensure you’re getting enough.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Is Gluten-Free Bread Healthier Than Regular Bread?
item.description: Experts say there are important distinctions to keep in mind.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Welcome to Wrexham: It’s the Future
item.description: Rob McElhenney and Ryan Reynolds seem sincere about their investment, emotionally and financially, in a Welsh soccer team. But they are not mere observers in its story.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
